> I change interfaces all the time, but I consider this to be something
> right, not something wrong. I think my process is good because I
> don't need to consider whether an interface I'm developing now will
be
> workable in the future; I just need to get it to work with what I
> need now--a much simpler and faster job--and leave it at that. 

I think we need to define terms a little.  Interface in this context is
a little overloaded.  I took it to mean the conceptual boundary between
any part of my system that talks to any other part.  And with that
definition, I'd agree with your statements (I do the same).

Hmm.  Now I was prepared to say that if you're talking about an
Interface as an API to a set of developers that are outside your group,
then frequent change may be a bad thing.  However, that situation just
makes those one of your customers, I'd say.

Which means that the *real* question would be:  How do you prioritize
requests from several different customers.  That's a more
straightforward question, I think.  Or at least it sounds a lot like
someone else's problem.  :P

(sorry for all the handwaving there...)

Kevin
